title: Are feelings in any way significant to moral judgement? - Quora

As feelings are a considerate aspect of the human condition, of our reality, I would emphatically say yes. The caveat, however, is a strong one: feelings, an instinctive actuation for the most part, are entirely subjective. (Please no cartesian objections…). They themselves are as subject to moral/ethical evaluation as any other human activity. They are not always good; they can be learned reactions to any stimuli, good or evil. Feel good about your professional adversary’s downfall? Likely immoral.

Yes. Moral judgement is the product of one's feelings, experience, alongside knowledge about the situation. Let us take an example of being compassionate— one of the qualities of a morally good person. How can you have such a quality without having feelings for others’ misfortunes? I guess emotion intelligence ( empathy) is the key to an objective moral judgment.
